Dear Sheffield City Council,
I would like to request under the Freedom of Information Act data I believe to be held by your authority concerning marriages.
In particular, I would like to request information on what documentation prospective couples have to present to prove they are not related.
I would like to know the number of marriages which were blocked or prevented from proceeding because of a lack of this proof.
In addition, I would like to know the number of marriages in your area for the past five years. Can you break down this figure to show marriages between First Cousins?
Could this figure be broken down to include the ethnicity of both parties and their gender.
Also, I would like to know any policy or guidance you may have concerning the marriage of first or second cousins.
I would appreciate it if this information could be supplied in an Excel or CSV format.
Yours faithfully,
Darren Boyle

Dear Darren Boyle,
Thank you for your request for information relating to marriages which we
received on 11/12/2024.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 14/01/2024. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.

Dear Darren Boyle,
Thank you for your request for information relating to marriages which we
received on 11/12/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
• In particular, I would like to request information on what
documentation prospective couples have to present to prove they are
not related.
Giving notice for a marriage or civil partnership must be given 28 days
before a ceremony and this is a legal requirement. The guidance for
documentation for giving notice is on the government website at
[1]
https://www.gov.uk/marriages-civil-partn...
When a notice is conducted the couple who are getting married are asked a
series of questions one of those questions being:
Are you related to each other by blood, marriage, civil partnership or
adoption
The couple will sign a legal document to state they are not related to
each other.
• I would like to know the number of marriages which were blocked or
prevented from proceeding because of a lack of this proof.
We do not hold this information as any marriages blocked and for what
reason is held by the General Registration Office (GRO), we do not make
the decisions on whether someone can marry or enter a civil partnership.
We pass all evidence to the GRO and they make the decision on that
evidence. If more evidence is required, we would ensure any further
evidence is passed through our office to the GRO, please note that all
evidence will be verified by Registrar from the register office and only
original documents would be stamped and signed for. Any evidence that is
not an original document we would advise that they obtain the original or
apply for a copy from the relevant UK department or country for the
documents originated. If documentation is not supplied a ceremony will not
be conducted.
• In addition, I would like to know the number of marriages in your area
for the past five years. Can you break down this figure to show
marriages between First Cousins?
┌──────────────────┬─────────────────────────────┬─────────────────────────────┐
│ Year │ Wedding Ceremonies │ Civil Partnerships │
├──────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2020 │ 1414 │ 64 │
├──────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2021 │ 1780 │ 22 │
├──────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2022 │ 1780 │ 68 │
├──────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2023 │ 1740 │ 87 │
├──────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2024 │ 1742 │ 71 │
└──────────────────┴─────────────────────────────┴─────────────────────────────┘
We do not hold any records of whether the couple is a first cousin, again
you would need to enquire with GRO whether they hold these records.
• Could this figure be broken down to include the ethnicity of both
parties and their gender.
We do not hold any records on ethnicity of couples or of their gender, you
will need to enquire with the GRO if they hold these statistics.
• Also, I would like to know any policy or guidance you may have
concerning the marriage of first or second cousins.
All guidance comes from a marriage act and currently this is the Marriage
Act 1949, the GRO also provides guidance on this to each register office
and any amendments to the Act are put in place when they are made.
The current guidance in Part 1 Marriage Act 1949 (please note below is a
broken-down version of the Act from GRO guidance).
Void relationships – Part 1.9
The following list details relationships by blood or adoption which are
not permitted for marriage purposes and would make the marriage void:
Adoptive child
Adoptive parent
Child
Former adoptive child
Former adoptive parent
Grandparent
Grandchild
Parent
Parent’s sibling
Sibling
Sibling’s child
Half-blood relationship is as much an impediment to marriage as whole
blood relationship. The restrictions still apply if a person’s parents
were not married to each other at the time of their birth.
(Please note that we would not take a notice of marriage or civil
partnership for any of the above details),
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
